stories.title: How fast is it warming up this year compared to last year where I live?
stories.tagline: This graph shows the heat accumulated across the year at a single location, and how that compares to previous years.
stories.description:
What am I looking at?

This graph shows the daily accumulation of heat (also known as “Growing Degree Days”) for the current year at your location, and compares it to previous years of heat accumulation. The long-term average of accumulation over the period of 1981-2010 is shown in black, the current year in blue, and the prior year in orange. You can also see the prediction for accumulation over the next 6 days, shown in red.

What does this tell me?

Heat accumulation is a metric of climate that is a common driver of phenological activity. Many species respond by leafing, flowering, or emerging at particular heat accumulation thresholds. This graph can show you whether heat is accumulating faster than normal where you live, which may mean earlier than average signs of phenological activity.

How can I modify this graph?

If there is a particular heat accumulation threshold that is of interest to you, you can set the threshold in the Features menu to see if it has been met and if so, when. In addition, you can modify the Degree Base temperature for the accumulation curve and the Location in the Layer/Point menu.

stories.title: Where did spring arrive early this year?
stories.tagline: This map shows where spring leaf out arrived earlier or later compared to the long-term average.
stories.description:
What am I looking at?

This map shows where spring leaf out arrived earlier or later this year compared to the long-term average based on the period from 1981-2010. The map is based on an integrative model that predicts the start of spring called the Spring Indices. This model was developed using a long-term dataset of lilacs and honeysuckles and has been identified as a climate change indicator by the U.S. Global Change Research Program.

What does this tell me?

Locations that are red are earlier than the average start of spring leaf out and locations that are blue are later than the average date. Early spring leaf out may result in a greater risk of frost damage to plants that begin leafing out or flowering before final winter frost events.

How can I modify this visualization?

You can change the map displayed by changing the Layer Category in the Map menu. Within the Spring Indices category, you can display either the Leaf or Bloom model, and view annual historical maps and current year status and anomaly maps.

stories.title: Are milkweed leaves available when monarch caterpillars need them?
stories.tagline: This Activity Curve shows the overlap between leaves in milkweed plants and activity of monarch butterfly caterpillars in the Midwest this year.
stories.description:
What am I looking at?

This Activity Curve shows the overlap between the proportion of invidual milkweed plants with leaves and the mean number of monarch active caterpillars observed in Midwest states in 2019. You can see the change in the proportion of individuals with leaves and number of caterpillars in each 2-week period across the year.

What does this tell me?

Observers started reporting milkweed leaves in late April in the Midwest, and by early June, all observers were reporting a 'yes' for leaves. Observers started reporting monarch caterpillars in late May, with a peak in number of caterpillars observed in early July. Activity of caterpillars started to decline in September, and as of October, milkweed leaves were still being reported.

How can I modify this visualization?

You can explore other metrics such as Total Yes Records and Number of Animals per Hour in the Curves menu. You can also use the Curves menu to change the pheno classes displayed. You can also use this menu to add additional curves for other Years, Taxanomic Groups or Phenophase Classes.

stories.title: When will northern red oak change color this fall?
stories.tagline: This Phenology Calendar shows reports of colored leaves from the past four years.
stories.description:
What am I looking at?

This Phenology Calendar shows when observers reported the colored leaves phenophase for Northern red oak across Northeast states from 2015 to 2018. The colored line indiciates at least one observer reported 'yes' for colored leaves on that day. The gray line indicates at least one observer reported 'no' for colored leaves on that day, and no observer reported 'yes.'

What does this tell me?

You can use this Calendar to know when to expect colored leaves on Northern red oak in the fall. Aside from a few stray reports of colored leaves in the summer months, the majority of 'yes' reports for colored leaves begin around mid- to late-September.

How can I modify this visualization?

You can change the Species (or higher Taxonomic group) and Phenophase Class displayed on the Calendar in the Select Species/Phenophase menu and the Years displayed in the Years menu. To change the location from the Northeast to a different area, use the Boundary menu. You can change the size of the labels and color bands as well as whether the 'no' data are displayed in the Features menu.

stories.title: How does winter temperature relate to leafing in the Soapberry family?
stories.tagline: This scatterplot graph shows how minimum winter temperatures relate to the onset of spring leafing in the Soapberry family, which includes maples and chestnuts.
stories.description:
What am I looking at?

This graph shows the relationship between minimum winter temperatures and the onset of leafing within the Soapberry family (Sapindaceae) using all available data across the United States for the years 2010-2019. The relationship is calculated as a simple linear regression between these two variables. The onset dates for leafing are the first observed date of the leaf phenophases for a given individual plant and year.

What does this tell me?

Minimum winter temperatures can drive phenological activity in the spring. In some species, colder temperatures have been found to suppress leaf-out whereas warmer temperatures promote earlier leaf-out. In this case, warmer temperatures are associated with earlier leaf-out within species of the Soapberry family.

How can I modify this visualization?

You can change the Species and Phenophase Class displayed on the Scatterplot in the Species/Phenophase menu and the years displayed in the Years menu. To set a more specific location use the Boundary menu. Using the Features menu you can change the size of the labels and color bands as well as which climatic variables you are exploring. You can also add an additional set of data points grouped by taxonomy to the scatterplot.

stories.title: Where did eastern tent caterpillars first emerge in southern states in 2019?
stories.tagline: This Pheno Forecast shows when enough heat had accumulated to trigger emergence of eastern tent caterpillars.
stories.description:
What am I looking at?

This Pheno Forecast shows the first locations (in yellow) to reach the required accumulation of heat to trigger emergence of eastern tent caterpillars in 2019, which occured on March 10. The map also shows bands of color indicating locations that are 2-3 weeks, 1-2 weeks, and 7 days away from emergence, as well as those that are in areas of delining activity and past the time of caterpillar activity.

What does this tell me?

Our Pheno Forecasts predict key life cycle stages in invasive and pest species. These maps help managers to know when to expect emergence to more effectively plan treatment actities. Learn more about these Pheno Forecasts at www.usanpn.org/data/forecasts.

How can I modify this visualization?

We have Pheno Forecasts available for other insect pests and invasive plants. You can change the species displayed by selecting from the Base Layer menu. You can also use the Base Layer menu to change the date of the forecast by choosing a date from the calendar. You can also add observations of eastern tent caterpillars collected through Nature's Notebook by going to the Species/Phenophase menu and selecting a Species (or higher Taxonomic group) and Phenophase Class.
